results.notes:
Location: Brooklyn neighborhood, Portland, OR.
Habit: Scattered. Solitary or cespitose.
Substrate: Growing out of soil in flowerbed. Some conifers, holly, and unknown bushes in flowerbed.
Cap: 4-7cm across. Convex to planed with a slight umbo. Inrolled margin when young. Wavy in age. Scaly. Dark brown in the center and lightening toward margin. Surface dry. Margin has a slightly translucent striate.
Gills: Close. Cream colored. Slightly notched.
Stipe: 4-6cm long. 1-1.5cm thick at apex. Bulbous at base and tapering or rooting below base. Creamy colored with pinkish hue.
Partial Veil: Cobwebby and high on stipe.
Flesh: White. Solid.
Odor: Mild.
Taste: Mild.

results.notes:
While most of my encounters have been from floodplain forest, this is from upland, predominantly northern pin oak, forest on sandy soil.
And while most encounters have been with dried whitened and contorted specimens, these were (confusingly) fresh. These were on a small cherry log. The big one about 2 cm across was collected and produced a white spore print. It dried with a white cap and dark brown gills. Interesting to compare this with the revived specimen from August 11. Similarities are evident.
On the same cherry log, same date, was a much smaller trio which I intuited might be the same species as the big one. These I did not collect but a follow-up photo from 9-16 shows them much shrunken and curled, with cracked, whitened caps and dark gills.

results.notes:
Collected by Bill Sheehan. Growing on wood in mixed forest. Surfaces slowly bruising yellow-brown. Associated with a white rot. Spines up to 2.2 mm long. Odor not distinctive. No reaction with 10% FeSO4 on surfaces. Monomitic with clamps. Fusiform gloeocystidia present. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores amyloid. hyaline and smooth. Spore measurements: (3.6) 3.7 – 4.8 (5.4) × (2.9) 3.1 – 3.8 (3.9) µm; Q = (1) 1.1 – 1.3 (1.4); N = 30; Me = 4.2 × 3.4 µm; Qe = 1.2

results.notes:
Wrinkled cups growing on a mossy log; connected to the substrate by a short central stem-like nub.
Spores mostly smooth, a few finely punctate (the smaller ones more apt to be ornamented), lacking guttules; 12-15 × 7-9.
AF of NA and C du Q each report spore dimensions for P. varia that are longer than the ones from this collection. Range of spore dimensions reported by ME for P. repanda is a very good match for these. AF of NA says that P. repanda has been synonymized with P. varia and that P. varia takes preference; lack of sufficiently different macroscopic/microscopic traits between the varia and repanda concepts is cited. But, ME provides spore dimensions for repanda that support the two-species idea. Assuming this, the collection seen here appears to be a candidate for being named Peziza repanda.

results.notes:
Under Scots pine, some small oaks present.
No latex found.
The purple bruising on the cut stipes and sliced gills is accurately portrayed in the photo. This feature is not mentioned in any description of R. brevipes that I have found.
Spores 8-9 × 6-7; very small isolated warts, not exceeding 0.5 microns in height. This spore morphology agrees with what is reported on ME, but is much different than the C du Q account of R. brevipes. It’s almost as if ME and C du Q document two completely different species… and neither mentions purple staining on the cut context.
The cap surfaces on these two mushrooms darkened significantly after 36 hours (as seen in last photo).

results.notes:
Growing on bits of leaves, twigs and bits of bark among leaf litter on the bank of Greenbrier Road near Carpinus carolinaiana, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Tilia americana, Liriodendron tulipifera, Magnolia acuminata, Rhododendron sp. and Acer sp. Caps convex; pale gray; slightly hygrophanous with cap centers drying slightly pinkish-brown; slightly sulcate; 2.6 to 3.7 mm wide and 1.7 to 1.8 mm tall. Gills white and adnate to short-decurrent with 1 tier of lamellulae; 12 full-length lamellae reaching the stem. Stems smooth and dry with slightly bulbous bases and white basal mycelium; 5.9 to 9.0 mm long and 0.3 mm wide. Odor not distinctive. Pileipellis a cutis with excrescences. Subpellis and lamellar trama vinescent in Melzer’s. Pleurocystidia absent (?). Cheilocystidia hyaline, smooth, thin-walled and fusiform; some apically branched. Cheilocystidia measurements: (20.8) 31.8 – 43.3 (46.4) × (7.3) 8.4 – 11.7 (16.1) µm; Q = (2) 2.7 – 4.6 (4.8); N = 20; Me = 36 × 10.3 µm; Qe = 3.6. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores immediately strongly amyloid, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (5.1) 6 – 8.3 (9.2) × (3.5) 3.6 – 4.8 (5.9) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.5 – 1.88 (1.9); N = 30; Me = 7 × 4.2 µm; Qe = 1.7

In a swamp at very base of a red maple stub.

Returning on November 10 I found the whole thing loosely attached and actually quite thin (about 1 mm?) and pliable/leathery but not tough (easily torn).

results.notes:
Collected with Jacob Kalichman. Locally abundant. Growing on the bark of a live Quercus sect. Quercus toward the base of the tree, as well as on adjacent twigs. Caps convex to pulvinate and centrally depressed; dry; 3.0 to 23.6 mm wide and 1.8 to 9.4 mm tall. Gills short decurrent, widely spaced and slightly intervenose. Stems with pale brown pruina and finely strigose paled brown basal mycelium; texture cartilaginous; not releasing liquid when cut; 3.2 to 14.7 mm long and 0.7 to 1.8 mm wide. Some stems laterally compressed. Surfaces not fluorescing. Odor and taste not distinctive. Clamps scattered in the pileipellis. Clamps present in the stipe trama. Caulocystidia scattered, lightly-encrusted, with hyaline or brown intracellular content. Crystalline material abundant on lamellar surfaces and in subhymenium. All lamellar structures inamyloid. Clamps and lactifers present in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia scattered; hyaline; fusiform; some with tapered, flexuose and/or branched apices. Basidia 4-stergimate and clavate. Mature basidia difficult to locate. Spores white in mass. Spores immediately and tardily inamyloid, hyaline and smooth. Spore measurements: (7.3) 7.4 – 8.8 (9.2) × (4) 4.1 – 5 (5.7) µm; Q = (1.5) 1.7 – 1.9; N = 30; Me = 8.2 × 4.6 µm; Qe = 1.8.
